ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A deeper understanding of masculinity theory, medical anthropology as a field, and various approaches to health on different diseases in different parts of the globe.
Ethnographic theories regarding the construction of masculinity and gender theory.
Insight about a field in gender studies that I haven't given much thought to relating to masculinity & men's health. Also, exposure to ethnographic writing and thinking.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strenghts: the book club format is great. I'm often disappointed at undergraduate seminars' lack of depth, but the student led discussions and Marcia's interventions make discussion flow well and with substance which made for deep discussions. The assignment structure was also very good to keep us engaged and not have work pile up. 
 
Weakness: None if you do the readings.

She experimented with not have response posts, which did make the work easier, but might have also made it more difficult to engage in the course and to show it if people were feeling a little nonverbal that day.
Very interesting dicussions and ehtnographies but  students could have more creativity/freedom when it comes to structuring their leadership discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes yes yes! If you are interested in WGSS, health anthro or are a man who wants to think deeper about how masculinity affects your personal relationships and others.
Very good course, excellent if you want to have a better understanding of masculinity theory and the ways various cultures construct and interpret that.
Yes! This could be a very helpful course for anyone interested in gender studies or public health. Changes the way you think about gender, masculinity and health in ways you might not expect.
